awd_titl_txt: Travel: Support for U.S. Students to Receive Training on Research Cyberinfrastructure at the 2023 Annual Modeling and Simulation Conference (ANNSIM)
awd_abstract_narration:
This award supports up to 7 U.S.-based graduate students whose training on the research cyberinfrastructure will substantially benefit by attending the Annual Modeling and Simulation conference (ANNSIM), which is the flagship conference of the Society for Modeling & Simulation (SCS). ANNSIM will train students by providing access to expertise through twelve tracks. In particular, cyberinfrastructure training will be provided through presentations of simulation software tools in the Annual Simulation Symposium as well as model libraries, repositories, and data formats in the Theory and Foundations track. Since advanced networks are important for  cyberinfrastructure, ANNSIM also provides a track on telecommunication systems, which covers topics such as software defined networking, edge computing, or green and energy efficient communications. Improving the use of existing datasets and software, while supporting advances in networking, software developments, standards and certifications, will contribute to cyberinfrastructure research. In addition to these twelve tracks, ANNSIM includes several in-depth tutorials, taught by international experts in their field. The twelve tracks and the tutorials ensure that attendees are well-aware of advances in information technology systems through advanced software, data, networked systems, and simulation environments. By providing access to leading experts, ANNSIM ensures that the next generation of scientists has the tools, motivations, and career aspirations to contribute to cyberinfrastructure. Every NSF-funded participant will be matched with a mentor chosen among the experienced scholars in attendance, which will help build a professional network. 

This award contributes to cyberinfrastructure training by supporting the attendance of up to 7 US-based students at the Annual Modeling Modeling and Simulation conference (ANNSIM). The conference will include a direct learning component by providing multiple tutorials, so that students can develop skills in specific software packages or apply advanced techniques relevant to the research cyberinfrastructure. This research can range from software for digital twins to datasets and libraries in model-driven system design. The conference gives particular attention to students (e.g., PhD Colloquium with presentations followed by interactive poster sessions), which helps them connect with leading researchers to identify better tools and/or additional datasets for experiments. A barrier in cyberinfrastructure training students is not necessarily a lack of existing tools or repositories, but a lack of awareness about these tools. Keynote speakers in simulation conferences have a reputation for informing and motivating students in contributing to the cyberinfrastructure, for instance by covering methods and software for system and application performance. Attending these talks will ensure that students have specific directions to apply the tools that they have gained onto open research problems in the cyberinfrastructure. Students will submit articles and receive feedback from the technical program committee in each track. The selection committee seeks students who are enrolled in an eligible US-based accredited college or university, lack access to sufficient funding to attend the conference, and have an accepted submission. The committee will make special efforts to encourage the application of members of under-represented groups and form a balanced mix of award recipients.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Modeling and Simulation has been used for several decades. This research field has a close relation with cyberinfrastructure, since a successful cyberinfrastructure articulates data, software, and high-fidelity simulation models. As the flagship conference of the Society for Modeling and Simulation International, the Annual Modeling and Simulation conference (ANNSIM) is an essential venue for students to acquire new skills in the cyberinfrastructure. The 2023 ANNSIM was held in the Greater Toronto Area, Canada. This project supported the active participation of students at institutions of higher education in the USA. Their active participation is important to train the next generation of researchers. Thanks to support from the NSF, seven U.S.-based students have attended ANNSIM, where they received mentoring and cyberinfrastructure training. These students fulfiled several elligibility criteria (enrolled in an eligible US-based accredited college or university; lacking access to sufficient funding to attend the conference; and have an accepted submission) and special efforts from the assessment committee encouraged applications of members of under-represented groups. By focusing on the next generation of researchers, this project contributes to the advancement of science in the various tracks covered by the conference, ranging from digital twins and sustainability to cybersecurity and health informatics.

During ANNSIM, the seven young scholars supported by the NSF have enjoyed a range of tailored activities including connecting in small groups with seasoned scholars in the research community, attending an interactive panel on careers (composed of a junior scholar, senior scholar, and industry representative), learning the technical skills to contribute to specific aspects of the cyberinfrastructure via a series of tutorials, and attending the presentations of peer-reviewed articles (published online by the IEEE) in topical tracks. 

By immersing themselves into such a creative environment, the young scholars supported by the NSF acquired the foundations for some of the research work that they are currently conducting. Talking with other researchers and watching their presentations also helped them identify gaps in the current body of research that they can address, while providing concrete pointers to start addressing these research gaps. Finally, by establishing connections with some of the most prominent researchers in the field, this project has supported a diverse array of young scholars in becoming contributing members of the research workforce. Overall, this project had a significant impact at a critical stage of the early career of seven young scientists, which will create a strong and sustained effect over the next generation of researchers in modeling and simulation.
